case_data.name: United States v. State of Hawaii
special_collections: Trump Administration 2.0: Litigation and Investigations Involving the Government
case_data.summary:
On April 30, 2025, the United States filed this lawsuit against Hawai'i, its Governor, and its Attorney General in the United States District Court for the District of Hawai'i. The DOJ brought this action after it learned that the state of Hawai'i had plans to bring a lawsuit against fossil fuel companies to hold them liable for their contribution to climate change and its effects. The DOJ argued that such a lawsuit was pre-empted by the Clean Air Act and the federal government's control over foreign affairs, that it would constitute unconstitutional regulation by a state of territory outside the state, and that it would violate the Interstate Commerce and Foreign Commerce Clauses. Specifically, the DOJ argued that through the Clean Air Act, the Congress anointed the federal EPA as the regulator of greenhouse gas emissions, and therefore, under the Supremacy Clause, states were pre-empted from regulating greenhouse gas emissions through state law. The DOJ asked the court to declare that Hawai'i's state law claims were unconstitutional, and to permanently enjoin Hawai'i from taking actions to assert Hawai'i's state law claims.

Despite this lawsuit, Hawai'i went ahead with its climate change lawsuit the next day, May 1, in the Circuit Court for the First Circuit of Hawai'i, naming seven fossil fuel companies as defendants. State of Hawai‘i v. BP p.l.c., No. 1CCV-25-0000717 (Haw. Cir. Ct. filed May 1, 2025). Hawai'i brought state claims of negligence, public nuisance, private nuisance, trespass, harm to public trust resources, civil aiding and abetting, unfair or deceptive acts or practices, and strict liability for failure to warn. The State argued that the fossil fuel companies had known for decades about the harmful effects of fossil fuel emissions, and to protect their businesses, "mounted a decades-long campaign of deception to discredit the scientific consensus on climate change; create doubt in the minds of consumers, the media, business leaders, and the public about the climate change impacts of burning fossil fuels; and delay the energy economy's transition to a lower-carbon future while maximizing their own profits."

On June 17, in the First Circuit of Hawai'i, Defendants filed a motion to stay proceedings pending resolution of their action against the State in the District Court. 

The case is ongoing.

On April 30, 2025, the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) filed a lawsuit against the State of Hawaiโi, its Governor, and Attorney General in the U.S. District Court for the District of Hawaiโi. The DOJ initiated this suit after learning of Hawaiโiโs plans to sue fossil fuel companies for their contributions to climate change. The DOJ argued that Hawaiโiโs proposed lawsuit was pre-empted by the federal Clean Air Act, which grants the EPA the authority to regulate greenhouse gas emissions, making state action in this area unconstitutional under the Supremacy Clause. The DOJ also claimed Hawaiโiโs actions would improperly regulate conduct outside its borders and violate the Interstate and Foreign Commerce Clauses. The DOJ sought a declaration that Hawaiโiโs state law claims were unconstitutional and an injunction to prevent Hawaiโi from proceeding.

Nevertheless, on May 1, 2025, Hawaiโi filed its climate change lawsuit in state court against seven fossil fuel companies, citing negligence, nuisance, trespass, harm to public trust resources, civil aiding and abetting, unfair or deceptive practices, and failure to warn. Hawaiโi alleged the companies deliberately misled the public about the dangers of fossil fuels. After defendants moved to stay state proceedings, the court partially granted the motion, pausing the case pending the federal courtโs resolution. The litigation is ongoing.

COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF 

Case 1:25-cv-00179     Document 1     Filed 04/30/25     Page 2 of 31  PageID.2
 
Plaintiff United States of America bring this civil action against Defendants 
and alleges as follows: 
INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The United States is facing an energy crisis. Overly restrictive policies 
and regulation have caused inadequate development of Americaโs abundant energy 
resources. Yet โ[a]n affordable and reliable domestic energy supply is essential to 
the national and economic security of the United States, as well as our foreign 
policy.โ Executive Order 14260, Protecting American Energy From State 
Overreach ยง 1.  
2.  As a result, on January 20, 2025, President Trump declared an energy 
emergency, concluding that the United Statesโ โinsufficient energy production, 
transportation, refining, and generation constitutes an unusual and extraordinary 
threat to our Nationโs economy, national security, and foreign policy.โ Executive 
Order 14156, Declaring a National Energy Emergency ยง 1.  
3.  As a result of state restrictions and burdens on energy production, the 
American people are paying more for energy, and the United States is less able to 
defend itself from hostile foreign actors. Id. 
4.  Hawaii intends to sue fossil fuel companies to seek damages for 
alleged climate change harms. See Sam Spangler, Hawaii To File Lawsuit Against 
Fossil Fuel Companies, Khon2 (Apr. 28, 2025), https://www.khon2.com/local-
2 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00179     Document 1     Filed 04/30/25     Page 3 of 31  PageID.3
 
news/hawaii-to-file-lawsuit-against-fossil-fuel-companies/ (โโWe will be filing 
suit, I believe, on Thursday against the fossil fuel companies. They have to pay 
their share because climate change and the climate impact is definitely connected 
to generations of extra fossil fuel thatโs been burned.โโ). At a time when States 
should be contributing to a national effort to secure reliable sources of domestic 
energy, Hawaii is choosing to stand in the way. This Nationโs Constitution and 
laws do not tolerate this interference. 
JURISDICTION AND VENUE 
 
5.  This Court has jurisdiction under 28 U.S.C. ยงยง 1331 and 1345. 
6.  This Court has authority to provide the relief requested under the U.S. 
Constitution, 28 U.S.C. ยงยง 1651, 2201, and 2202, and its inherent legal and 
equitable powers. 
7.  The United States has standing to vindicate its sovereign, proprietary, 
and parens patriae interests. E.g., Arizona v. United States, 567 U.S. 387 (2012). 
The United Statesโ sovereign interests include ensuring that States do not interfere 
with federal law, including the Clean Air Act, or with the federal governmentโs 
exclusive authority over interstate and foreign commerce, greenhouse gas 
regulation, and national energy policy. The United Statesโ proprietary interests 
include its economic interests in revenue from fossil fuel leasing on federal lands, 
3 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00179     Document 1     Filed 04/30/25     Page 4 of 31  PageID.4
which generated over $13.8 billion in 2024,1 and its costs for purchasing fossil 
fuels, which will increase if Hawaii and other states seek damages from fossil fuel 
companies. See City of New York v. Chevron Corp., 993 F.3d 81, 103 (2d Cir. 
2021) (observing that holding fossil fuel producers โaccountable for purely foreign 
activity (especially the Foreign Producers) would require them to internalize the 
costs of climate change and would presumably affect the price and production of 
fossil fuels abroad.โ). Additionally, the United States has parens patriae standing to 
protect the economic well-being of its citizens and the national energy market from 
Hawaiiโs attempts to impose extraterritorial and excessive burdens on fossil fuel 
companies, which will raise energy costs for consumers nationwide and disrupt the 
uniform regulation of fossil fuel production. These harms affect a substantial 
segment of the population, and individual litigants, such as fossil fuel businesses, 
cannot fully address the nationwide economic and constitutional injuries caused by 
Hawaiiโs overreach. 
1 The Department of the Interior manages land owned by the United States. The 
Department issues leases to produce fossil fuels from federal lands and for 
production in areas of the Outer Continental Shelf. Each year, the Department 
collects substantial revenue from those onshore and offshore leases. In 2024, the 
Department collected revenue of more than $490 million for coal, $950 million for 
gas, and $12.4 billion for oil. See U.S. DEPโT OF THE INTERIOR, NATURAL 
RESOURCES REVENUE DATA, https://revenuedata.doi.gov/ (last visited Apr. 
30, 2025). 
4 

Case 1:25-cv-00179     Document 1     Filed 04/30/25     Page 5 of 31  PageID.5
8. This Court has personal jurisdiction over Defendants because they
reside in, or conduct a substantial portion of their official business in, Hawaii. See 
Fed. R. Civ. P. 4(k)(1). 
9. Venue is proper in the District of Hawaii pursuant to 28 U.S.C.
ยง 1391, because at least one Defendant resides in the District and because a
substantial part of the acts giving rise to this suit occurred within the District. 
PARTIES 
10. Plaintiff is the United States of America, suing on its own behalf, on
behalf of its citizens, and on behalf of its executive departments and 
other subdivisions. 
11. Defendant State of Hawaii is a State of the United States.
12. Defendant Joshua Booth Green is the Governor of the State of Hawaii.
He is sued in his official capacity. 
13. Defendant Anne E. Lopez is the Attorney General of the State of
Hawaii. She is sued in her official capacity. 
ALLEGATIONS AND APPLICABLE LAW 
Hawaiiโs Climate Change Claims 
14. Hawaii has announced its intent to file litigation seeking to hold fossil
fuel companies liable for purported contributions to greenhouse gas emissions. See 
Sam Spangler, Hawaii To File Lawsuit Against Fossil Fuel Companies, Khon2 
5 

Case 1:25-cv-00179     Document 1     Filed 04/30/25     Page 6 of 31  PageID.6
(Apr. 28, 2025), https://www.khon2.com/local-news/hawaii-to-file-lawsuit-
against-fossil-fuel-companies/. The specific theories on which Hawaii would sue 
are known only to Hawaii, but the goal of the lawsuit is clearโto extract large 
sums of money from fossil fuel companies for purportedly causing climate change 
impacts to Hawaii. See id. (โโFrankly, fossil fuels deserve to pay their share,โ 
Governor Green said. โWe were able to weather all of those costs, but it would 
have been nice to have a couple of billion extra dollars from the fossil fuel 
companies. And I will be negotiating that over time.โโ). 
The Clean Air Act Comprehensively Regulates Nationwide Air Pollution 
15. The Clean Air Act, 42 U.S.C. ยง 7401 et seq., creates a comprehensive
program for regulating air pollution in the United States and โdisplacesโ the ability 
of States to regulate greenhouse gas emissions beyond their borders. City of New 
York, 993 F.3d at 96. The Act improves the Nationโs air quality by delegating 
authority to EPA to prescribe national standards for air pollutants, which States 
then implement. See, e.g., 42 U.S.C. ยง 7411. 
16. In Massachusetts v. EPA, 549 U.S. 497 (2007), the Supreme Court
concluded that greenhouse gases, such as carbon dioxide and methane, are within 
the Clean Air Actโs unambiguous definition of โair pollutant,โ 42 U.S.C. 
ยง 7602(g). Id. at 528-529. Thus, the Clean Air Act delegates to EPA authority to
6 

Case 1:25-cv-00179     Document 1     Filed 04/30/25     Page 7 of 31  PageID.7
 
set nationwide standards for greenhouse gases. See Am. Electric Power Co., Inc. v. 
Connecticut, 564 U.S. 410, 424-429 (2011) (AEP). 
17.  For in-state stationary sources, the Clean Air Act generally preserves 
the ability of States to adopt and enforce air pollution control requirements and 
limitations on in-state sources, so long as those are at least as stringent as the 
corresponding federal requirements. See 42 U.S.C. ยง 7416. For out-of-state 
sources, however, the โAct gives states a much more limited role,โ even if the 
pollution from those sources causes harm within their borders. City of New York, 
993 F.3d at 88. Affected States can: (1) comment on proposed EPA rules and 
certain permits and plans, see id. ยง 7607(d)(5), ยง 7475(a)(2), ยง 7410(a)(2)(C); 40 
C.F.R. ยง 51.102(a); (2) seek judicial review if their concerns are not addressed, see 
42 U.S.C. ยง 7607(b); and (3) petition EPA in certain instances, see id. 
ยง 7410(k)(5). 
The United Statesโ Foreign Policy on 
Greenhouse Gas Regulation and Energy Development 
 
18.  Greenhouse gas emissions โpresent[] a uniquely international problem 
of national concern.โ City of New York, 993 F.3d at 85. Regulating these emissions 
โimplicatesโ not only โthe conflicting rights of statesโ but also โour relations with 
foreign nations.โ Id. at 92.  
19.  Consistent with the Constitutionโs allocation of supremacy in the field 
of foreign policy to the federal government, see Hines v. Davidowitz, 312 U.S. 52, 
7 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00179     Document 1     Filed 04/30/25     Page 8 of 31  PageID.8
 
62 (1941), the federal government has demonstrated an active and continuous 
interest in reconciling protection of the environment, promotion of economic 
growth, and maintenance of national security when regulating greenhouse gas 
emissions and fossil fuels, see City of New York, 993 F.3d at 93 (recognizing 
responsibility of federal government in striking the right โbalanceโ in promoting 
these goals). The federal government has been actively exercising its authority here 
and has been continually evaluating national interests as is its responsibility under 
the Constitution. It has โin fact . . . addressedโ these interwoven issues on many 
occasions. Am. Ins. Assโn v. Garamendi, 539 U.S. 396, 421 (2003). 
20.  In 1987, Congress enacted the Global Climate Protection Act. See 
Pub. L. No. 100-204, Title XI, ยงยง 1101โ1106, 101 Stat. 1331, 1407โ09 (1987), 
reprinted as note to 15 U.S.C. ยง 2901. Among its other goals, the Protection Act 
provided that the United States should โwork toward multilateral agreementsโ on 
the issue of greenhouse gas emissions. Id. ยง 1103(a)(4), 101 Stat. at 1408. It 
assigned to the President and EPA the responsibility for devising a โcoordinated 
national policy on global climate change.โ Id. ยง 1103(b), 101 Stat. at 1408. And the 
Protection Act assigned to the President and the Secretary of State the 
responsibility for coordination of climate change policy โin the international 
arena.โ Id. ยง 1103(c), 101 Stat. at 1409. 
8 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00179     Document 1     Filed 04/30/25     Page 9 of 31  PageID.9
 
21.  In 1992, President George H. W. Bush signed, and the Senate 
unanimously approved, the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate 
Change, May 9, 1992, S. Treaty Doc. No. 102-38, 1771 U.N.T.S. 107 (entered into 
force Mar. 21, 1994), which has as its โultimate objective . . . stabilization of 
greenhouse gas concentrations in the atmosphere at a level that would prevent 
dangerous anthropogenic interference with the climate system.โ Id., Art. 2. 
22.  Under the Framework Convention, โ[a]ll Parties,โ including the 
United States, โshall . . . .  (b) [f]ormulate, implement, publish and regularly update 
national and, where appropriate, regional programmes containing measures to 
mitigate climate change by addressing anthropogenic emissions by sources and 
removals by sinks of all greenhouse gases not controlled by the Montreal Protocol, 
and measures to facilitate adequate adaptation to climate change [and] (c) 
[p]romote and cooperate in the development, application and diffusion, including 
transfer, of technologies, practices and processes that control, reduce or prevent 
anthropogenic emissions of greenhouse gases not controlled by the Montreal 
Protocol in all relevant sectors . . . .โ Id., Art. 4.1(b), (c). 
23.  The Framework Convention does not set binding limits on greenhouse 
gas emissions for individual countries. It contains no enforcement mechanism. 
Instead, it includes general obligations addressing climate change and creates a 
framework for cooperation by its parties. Among other things, it contemplates the 
9 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00179     Document 1     Filed 04/30/25     Page 10 of 31  PageID.10
 
possibility of its parties negotiating โprotocolsโ or other specific international 
agreements in pursuit of its objective. 
24.  Since approving the Framework Convention, the United States has 
engaged in international efforts regarding climate change and greenhouse gas 
emissions, balancing foreign policy considerations and domestic energy needs. In 
particular, the United States is also a party to the Kigali Amendment to the 
Montreal Protocol. See Amendment to the Montreal Protocol on Substances that 
Deplete the Ozone Layer, Oct. 15, 2016, S. Treaty Doc. No. 117-1, C.N.730.2017. 
The Amendment commits the United States and other signatory countries to phase 
down the production and consumption of hydrofluorocarbons, a greenhouse gas. 
The Senate ratified the Kigali Amendment in 2022, but only after Congress 
enacted the American Innovation and Manufacturing Act, 42 U.S.C. ยง 7675 in 
2020, giving EPA authority under the Clean Air Act to reduce production and 
consumption of hydrofluorocarbons. 
25.  By contrast, the United States is not a party to the Kyoto Protocol of 
1997, which provided for greenhouse gas emission reduction targets on UNFCCC 
Annex I parties, including the United States. Though the United States signed the 
protocol, President Clinton never submitted it to the Senate for ratification. Instead, 
the Senate passed a unanimous resolution expressing disapproval of any protocol 
10 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00179     Document 1     Filed 04/30/25     Page 11 of 31  PageID.11
 
or other agreement that provides for disparate treatment of economically 
developing countries. S. Res. 98, 105th Cong. (1997).  
26.  The United States is similarly not a party to the December 12, 2015 
Paris Climate Accord (the Paris Agreement). Paris Agreement to the United 
Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change, Dec. 13, 2015, in Rep. of the 
Conference of the Parties on the Twenty-First Session, U.N. Doc. 
FCCC/CP/2015/10/Add.1, annex (2016). In September 2016, President Obama 
signed the Paris Agreement but did not submit it to the Senate for ratification. On 
March 28, 2017, President Trump described how the United States would seek to 
reconcile the Nationโs environmental, economic, and strategic concerns. See Exec. 
Order 13,783, 82 Fed. Reg. 16,093 (Mar. 28, 2017).  On November 4, 2019, the 
United States deposited a notification of withdrawal from the Paris Agreement. 
Although on February 19, 2021, President Biden announced that he rejoined this 
expensive and destructive protocol, on February 13, 2025, President Trump 
withdrew the United States from the Paris Agreement. See Executive Order 14162, 
Putting America First in International Agreements ยง 3(a). The President explained 
that โ[i]t is the policy of my Administration to put the interests of the United States 
and the American people first in the development and negotiation of any 
international agreements with the potential to damage or stifle the American 
economyโ and that such agreements โmust not unduly or unfairly burden the 
11 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00179     Document 1     Filed 04/30/25     Page 12 of 31  PageID.12
 
United States.โ Id. ยง 2. In other words, the President would put the interests of the 
American people first in negotiating the terms of any future treaty to implement the 
Framework Convention 
27.  More recently, on April 2, 2025, President Trump invoked his 
authority under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act of 1977 to 
strengthen our Nationโs international economic position by imposing reciprocal 
tariffs on U.S. trading partners. See Executive Order 14257, Regulating Imports 
With a Reciprocal Tariff To Rectify Trade Practices That Contribute to Large and 
Persistent Annual United States Goods Trade Deficits. The Executive Order 
specifically exempts โenergy and energy productsโ from the tariffs. Id. ยง 3(b); see 
also Annex II. 
CLAIMS FOR RELIEF 
 
COUNT I 
Clean Air Act Preemption 
 
28.  The United States incorporates by reference all allegations stated 
above. 
29.  The Supremacy Clause of the United States Constitution provides that 
โ[t]his Constitution, and the Laws of the United States which shall be made in 
Pursuance thereof . . . shall be the supreme Law of the Land . . . any Thing in the 
12 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00179     Document 1     Filed 04/30/25     Page 13 of 31  PageID.13
 
Constitution or Laws of any State to the Contrary notwithstanding.โ U.S. Const. 
art. VI, cl. 2.  
30.  A state law is preempted under the Supremacy Clause when it 
intrudes into a field exclusively occupied by federal law (field preemption) or 
when it conflicts with federal law by standing as an obstacle to the accomplishment 
of Congressโs objectives (conflict preemption). See City of Milwaukee v. Illinois,

31.  Hawaiiโs state law claims are preempted by the Clean Air Act, 42 
U.S.C. ยงยง 7401 et seq., because they impermissibly regulate out-of-state 
greenhouse gas emissions and obstructs the Clean Air Actโs comprehensive 
federal-state framework and EPAโs regulatory discretion, see, e.g., Intโl Paper Co. 
v. Ouellette, 479 U.S. 481, 500 (1987) (โThe [Clean Water] Act pre-empts state 
law to the extent that the state law is applied to an out-of-state point source.โ); 
Arizona, 567 U.S. at 399-400 (discussing preemption). 
32.  โThe Clean Air Act is a comprehensive statutory scheme that anoints 
the EPA as the โprimary regulator of [domestic] greenhouse gas emissions.โ City of 
New York, 993 F.3d at 99 (quoting AEP, 564 U.S. at 428).  
33.  Congress delegated to EPA the authority to determine whether and 
how to regulate greenhouse gas emissions, thereby displacing federal common law

Case 1:25-cv-00179     Document 1     Filed 04/30/25     Page 14 of 31  PageID.14
 
claims and occupying the field of interstate air pollution regulation. See 
Massachusetts, 549 U.S. at 528-29 (holding that greenhouse gases are โair 
pollutantsโ under 42 U.S.C. ยง 7602(g)); AEP, 564 U.S. at 426 (โThe critical point 
is that Congress delegated to EPA the decision whether and how to regulate

of Milwaukee v. Illinois, 451 U.S. 304, 317 (1981) (holding that the Federal Water 
Pollution Control Actโs comprehensive regulatory program displaced federal

34.  The Clean Air Actโs comprehensive framework, which includes 
specific provisions for regulating emissions from stationary and mobile sources 
(see, e.g., 42 U.S.C. ยงยง 7410, 7411, 7521), preempts state attempts to regulate out-
of-state greenhouse gas emissions. See City of New York, 993 F.3d at 90-100. 
Hawaiiโs claims seeking to hold fossil fuel businesses liable for global greenhouse 
gas emissions usurp this federal authority. Hawaiiโs attempt to make fossil fuel 
companies โpay their shareโ for greenhouse gas emissions worldwide, most of 
which occur outside Hawaiiโs borders, is the type of state regulation of out-of-state 
greenhouse gas emissions preempted by the Clean Air Act. Sam Spangler, Hawaii 
To File Lawsuit Against Fossil Fuel Companies, Khon2 (Apr. 28, 2025),

https://www.khon2.com/local-news/hawaii-to-file-lawsuit-against-fossil-fuel-
companies/. 
35.  Hawaiiโs state law claims conflict with the Clean Air Actโs purposes 
and objectives by undermining its carefully calibrated cooperative federalism 
scheme and EPAโs discretion in regulating greenhouse gas emissions. 
36.  The Clean Air Act establishes a structured partnership between the 
federal government and States, allowing States to regulate in-state stationary 
sources under specific conditions, see, e.g., 42 U.S.C. ยงยง 7401(a)(3), 
7410(a)(2)(C), 7411(d), 7416, but limiting their role in regulating out-of-state or 
global emissions, see, e.g., 42 U.S.C. ยงยง 7410(a)(2)(C), 7410(k)(5), 7475(a)(2), 
7607(b). See also City of New York, 993 F.3d at 88. And the Clean Air Act 
contains a citizen-suit savings clause. 42 U.S.C. ยง 7604(e). When read together, the 
Clean Air Act โplainly permit[s] [S]tates to create and enforce their own emissions 
standards applicable to in-state polluters.โ City of New York, 993 F.3d at 99. This 
role โno doubt holds true for both state legislation and common law claims under

and has been interpreted to permit only state lawsuits brought under โthe law of the

15 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00179     Document 1     Filed 04/30/25     Page 16 of 31  PageID.16
 
37.  Hawaiiโs anticipated lawsuit โdoes not seek to take advantage of this 
slim reservoir of state common law.โ City of New York, 993 F.3d at 99. Rather, the 
Stateโs suit interferes with the Clean Air Actโs balance by effectively regulating 
out-of-state emissions. This extraterritorial regulation creates a patchwork of state-
level penalties that undermines state authority over pollution sources within state 
borders and frustrates the Clean Air Actโs goal of efficiency and predictability in

(holding that the Clean Air Actโs delegation to the EPA to regulate greenhouse gas

integrated approach to air pollution control. See Ouellette, 479 U.S. at 497; see 
also City of New York, 993 F.3d at 90-95. 
38.  Moreover, Hawaiiโs anticipated lawsuit obstructs EPAโs discretion to 
balance environmental, economic, and energy considerations in regulating 
greenhouse gases. The Clean Air Act grants EPA broad authority to promulgate 
regulations based on its expert judgment, including whether to impose emissions 
standards for stationary sources under 42 U.S.C. ยง 7411 and for mobile sources 
under 42 U.S.C. ยง 7521. By imposing retroactive liability for lawful conduct, 
Hawaii would second-guess EPAโs regulatory choices and imposes penalties that 
Congress did not authorize. 
16 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00179     Document 1     Filed 04/30/25     Page 17 of 31  PageID.17
 
39.  Hawaiiโs state law claims would further undermine federal objectives 
by increasing energy costs and disrupting the national energy market, contrary to 
the Clean Air Actโs integration with national energy policy. As noted in Executive 
Order 14156 (ยถ 2), insufficient energy production due to restrictive state policies

welfare and the productive capacity of its populationโ). 
40.  If Hawaii is permitted to pursue these sorts of state law claims, other 
States could pursue similar claims, leading to a chaotic โpatchworkโ of regulations 
that undermine the national interest in readily available and affordable energy and 
the governmentโs ability to effectively administer coherent national environmental

fragmentation would frustrate Congressโs intent for a unified federal approach to

41.  Thus, Hawaiiโs state law claims are preempted by the Clean Air Act. 
17 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00179     Document 1     Filed 04/30/25     Page 18 of 31  PageID.18
 
COUNT II 
Unconstitutional Extraterritorial Regulation 
 
42.  The United States incorporates by reference all allegations stated 
above. 
43.  The Constitutionโs structure and provisions, including the Due 
Process Clause, as well as concepts of State sovereignty and federalism, prohibit a 
State from regulating transactions, and imposing liability for conduct, occurring 
outside its borders. Hawaiiโs state law claims violate the Constitution by imposing 
extraterritorial liability for primarily out-of-state extraction and refining activities 
and out-of-state greenhouse gas emissions. Hawaiiโs anticipated lawsuit is 
irreconcilable with the Constitutionโs commitment of such matters to the federal 
government and the relative rights and obligations of the federal government and 
the States under the Constitution. 
44.  The United States has standing to assert this claim to protect its 
sovereign, proprietary, and parens patriae interests. Hawaiiโs anticipated lawsuit, 
which would seek extraterritorial liability, interferes with the federal governmentโs 
authority to regulate interstate and foreign commerce and greenhouse gas 
emissions, undermining national energy policy. The financial burdens of Hawaiiโs 
anticipated lawsuit on fossil fuel businesses increase the United Statesโ costs for 
purchasing fuels and threaten revenue from federal leasing. In its parens patriae 
capacity, the United States seeks to protect citizens nationwide from higher energy 
18 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00179     Document 1     Filed 04/30/25     Page 19 of 31  PageID.19
 
costs and economic disruption caused by Hawaiiโs anticipated overreach, which 
individual litigants cannot fully address due to the nationwide impact of Hawaiiโs 
state law claims. 
45.  The Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment provides: 
โ[N]or shall any State deprive any person of life, liberty, or property, without due 
process of law . . . .โ U.S. Const. amend. XIV, ยง 1. The fossil fuel businesses 
targeted by Hawaiiโs state law claims are persons under the Fourteenth 
Amendment. 
46.  The Constitutionโs structure and principles of due process mandate 
that while States are sovereign within their borders, they cannot regulate conduct 
beyond their borders, such as by imposing liability for pollution from out-of-state 
sources. โThe concept of Due Process constraints on a state legislatureโs ability to 
regulate subject matters and transactions beyond the stateโs boundaries, while 
perhaps infrequently litigated in those terms, is not new.โ Gerling Glob. 
Reinsurance Corp. of Am. v. Gallagher, 267 F.3d 1228, 1236-37 (11th Cir. 2001) 
(discussing Due Process limits on legislative jurisdiction). Indeed, โ[t]o resolve 
disputes about the reach of one Stateโs power,โ the Supreme Court โhas long 
consulted โฆ the Constitutionโs structure and the principles of โsovereignty and 
comityโ it embraces,โ along with โthe Due Process Clause.โ Natโl Pork Producers 
Council v. Ross, 598 U.S. 356, 376 (2023) (citation omitted). 
19 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00179     Document 1     Filed 04/30/25     Page 20 of 31  PageID.20
 
47.  It is a well-established โdue process principle that a state is without 
power to exercise โextra territorial jurisdiction,โ that is, to regulate and control 
activities wholly beyond its boundaries.โ  Watson v. Emps. Liab. Assur. Corp., 348 
U.S. 66, 70 (1954) (citing Home Ins. Co. v. Dick, 281 U.S. 397 (1930)). โThe 
sovereignty of each State, in turn, implie[s] a limitation on the sovereignty of all of 
its sister Statesโa limitation express or implicit in both the original scheme of the 
Constitution and the Fourteenth Amendment.โ World-Wide Volkswagen Corp. v. 
Woodson, 444 U.S. 286, 293 (1980). 
48.  Indeed, the Due Process Clause embodies โmore than a guarantee of 
immunity from inconvenient or distant litigationโ but also imposes โterritorial 
limitations on the power of the respective States.โ Bristol-Myers Squibb Co. v. 
Superior Ct. of California, San Francisco Cnty., 582 U.S. 255, 263 (2017) (quoting 
Hanson v. Denckla, 357 U.S. 235, 251 (1958)) (discussing how the sovereignty of 
each state imposes limitations on sovereignty of other states). 
49.  No single State can enact policies for the entire Nation, nor can a State 
โeven impose its own policy choice on neighboring States.โ BMW of N. Am., Inc. 
v. Gore, 517 U.S. 559, 570-71 (1996). โ[I]t follows from these principles of state 
sovereignty and comity that a State may not impose economic sanctions on 
violators of its laws with the intent of changing the tortfeasorsโ lawful conduct in 
other States.โ Id. at 572. โThe states are not nations, either as between themselves 
20 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00179     Document 1     Filed 04/30/25     Page 21 of 31  PageID.21
 
or towards foreign nations,โ and โtheir sovereignty stops short of nationality.โ New 
Hampshire v. Louisiana, 108 U.S. 76, 90 (1883). And โinterstate . . . pollution is a 
matter of federal, not state, law.โ Ouellette, 479 U.S. at 488. 
50.  Hawaiiโs state law claims violate the Constitutionโs structure and 
principles of due process by seeking to impose economic sanctions on fossil fuel 
businesses for economic activities that occurred primarily in other States and 
around the world. 
51.  Hawaiiโs anticipated lawsuit would improperly seek to โimpose strict 
liability for the damages caused by fossil fuel emissions no matter where in the 
world those emissions were released (or who released them),โ City of New York, 
993 F.3d at 93, including activities in other States and in foreign countries with no 
connection to Hawaii. โSuch a sprawlingโ scope โis simply beyond the limits of 
state law.โ Id. at 92. 
52.  Even if an entity has some contacts with Hawaii, such as in-state sales 
or operations, Hawaiiโs effort to collect damages for out-of-state greenhouse gas

53.  Moreover, the global scope of Hawaiiโs state law claims inherently 
overreaches by seeking to regulate conduct far beyond Hawaiiโs territorial 
21 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00179     Document 1     Filed 04/30/25     Page 22 of 31  PageID.22
 
jurisdiction, contravening the Due Process Clauseโs territorial limitations on state 
sovereignty. 
54.  Thus, Hawaiiโs state law claims violate the Constitutionโs limits on 
extraterritorial legislation. 
COUNT III 
Violation of the Interstate Commerce Clause 
 
55.  The United States incorporates by reference all allegations stated 
above. 
56.  The Constitution gives Congress โPower . . . [t]o regulate Commerce . 
. . among the several States.โ U.S. Const. art. I, ยง 8, cl. 3. 
57.  State laws that discriminate against interstate commerce are 
unconstitutional, even in the absence of federal legislation regulating the activity in 
question. Oklahoma Tax Commโn v. Jefferson Lines, Inc., 514 U.S. 175, 179 
(1995). 
58.  Hawaiiโs state law claims discriminate against interstate commerce 
facially, in practical effect, and in purpose by targeting commercial activityโfossil 
fuel extraction and refiningโthat occurs primarily if not exclusively in States other 
than Hawaii, including Texas, New Mexico, Louisiana, West Virginia, 
Pennsylvania, Oklahoma, and North Dakota. 
59.  Because Hawaiiโs state law claims discriminate against interstate 
commerce, strict scrutiny applies, and its anticipated lawsuit can be pursued only if 
22 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00179     Document 1     Filed 04/30/25     Page 23 of 31  PageID.23
 
โit advances a legitimate local purpose that cannot be adequately served by 
reasonable nondiscriminatory alternatives.โ New Energy Co. of Indiana v. 
Limbach, 486 U.S. 269, 278 (1988). 
60.  Upon information and belief, Hawaii has no legitimate local public 
interest in discriminating against interstate commerce. 
61.  Moreover, even if Hawaiiโs state law claims did not facially 
discriminate against interstate commerce and did not have non-discriminatory 
alternatives, it would still violate the Interstate Commerce Clause under the 
balancing test articulated in Pike v. Bruce Church, Inc., 397 U.S. 137, 142 (1970). 
Under Pike, a state law that regulates evenhandedly and has only incidental effects 
on interstate commerce is unconstitutional if the burden imposed on interstate 
commerce is โclearly excessive in relation to the putative local benefits.โ Id. 
62.  Hawaiiโs anticipated lawsuit would also impose substantial burdens 
on interstate commerce. By targeting fossil fuel businesses for extraction and 
refining activities and greenhouse gas emissions occurring primarily in other States 
and foreign countries, Hawaii would disrupt the national market for fossil fuels. 
Hawaiiโs request for damages would increase energy costs for consumers and 
businesses nationwide, as these costs are passed through the interstate energy

regulatory fragmentation, undermining the uniform national energy market. 
23 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00179     Document 1     Filed 04/30/25     Page 24 of 31  PageID.24
 
63.  Hawaiiโs state law claims would impose a substantial and undue 
burden on interstate commerce that is clearly excessive in relation to any putative 
local benefits. 
64.  Thus, Hawaiiโs anticipated lawsuit would violate the Interstate 
Commerce Clause. 
COUNT IV 
Violation of the Foreign Commerce Clause 
 
65.  The United States incorporates by reference all allegations stated 
above. 
66.  The Constitution provides that โ[t]his Constitution, and the Laws of 
the United States which shall be made in Pursuance thereof; and all Treaties made, 
or which shall be made, under the Authority of the United States, shall be the 
supreme Law of the Land; . . . any Thing in the Constitution or Laws of any State 
to the Contrary notwithstanding.โ  U.S. Const. art. VI, cl. 2. 
67.  The Constitution gives Congress the โPower . . . [t]o regulate 
Commerce with foreign Nations . . . .โ  U.S. Const. art. I, ยง 8, cl. 3. 
68.  The Foreign Commerce Clause has a negative application. Thus, for 
example, State laws that impose taxes on foreign commerce โwill not survive 
Commerce Clause scrutiny if the taxpayer demonstrates that the taxโ implicates 
one of the four concerns identified in Complete Auto Transit, Inc. v. Brady, 430 
U.S. 274, 279 (1977). A State law imposing taxes is unconstitutional if it (1) 
24 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00179     Document 1     Filed 04/30/25     Page 25 of 31  PageID.25
 
applies to an activity lacking a substantial nexus to the State; (2) is not fairly 
apportioned; (3) discriminates against interstate commerce; or (4) is not fairly 
related to the services provided by the State. See Barclays Bank PLC v. Franchise 
Tax Bd. Of California, 512 U.S. 298, 310-11 (1994) (citing Complete Auto, 430 
U.S. at 279). โIn the unique context of foreign commerce, a Stateโs power is 
further constrained because of the special need for federal uniformity.โ Id. at 311 
(cleaned up). Thus, โ[a] tax affecting foreign commerce therefore raises two 
concerns in addition to the four delineated in Complete Auto.โ Id. โThe first is 
prompted by the enhanced risk of multiple taxation. The second relates to the 
Federal Governmentโs capacity to speak with one voice when regulating 
commercial relations with foreign governments.โ Id. (cleaned up). 
69.  Hawaiiโs anticipated lawsuit is not a state tax. But the same limiting 
principles that apply to a Stateโs power to impose taxes on foreign commerce also 
apply to a Stateโs power to impose penalties, fines, and other civil liability on 
foreign commerce. 
70.  Hawaiiโs state law claims discriminate against foreign commerce 
facially, in practical effect, and in purpose by imposing penalties or fines that 
directly and substantially burden foreign commerce. Hawaii would seek to impose 
liability on fossil fuel businesses for activitiesโextraction and refining of fossil 
fuelsโthat occurred โworldwideโ in foreign countries. Hawaii would seek to 
25 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00179     Document 1     Filed 04/30/25     Page 26 of 31  PageID.26
 
impose liability on these foreign activities even though they lack a substantial 
nexus to Hawaii. Hawaii also would discriminate against foreign commerce and 
imposes liability that is not fairly related to the services provided by the State. 
Hawaiiโs anticipated lawsuit would enhance the risk of multiple States imposing 
overlapping liability on foreign commerce for the same activities. And it would 
harm the federal governmentโs capacity to speak with one voice when conducting 
commercial relations with foreign governments on issues such as regulation of 
greenhouse gas emissions, trade policy, exports and imports of fossil fuels, and 
national security.  
71.  The United States does not challenge Hawaiiโs authority to regulate 
the local activities of international corporations, such as emissions from in-state 
facilities or taxes on in-state sales. Ordinary state regulations that incidentally 
affect foreign commerce without such extraterritorial scope or federal interference 
remain permissible under the Foreign Commerce Clause. But Hawaiiโs anticipated 
lawsuit does not fall within this permissible role for States. Rather, Hawaiiโs 
attempt to take โa couple billion extra dollars from the fossil fuel companiesโ for 
worldwide extraction and refining with minimal nexus to Hawaii, imposes a 
disproportionate burden on foreign commerce, and undermine the federal 
governmentโs ability to maintain uniformity in regulating environmental, trade, and 
national security policy. 
26 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00179     Document 1     Filed 04/30/25     Page 27 of 31  PageID.27
 
72.  Thus, Hawaiiโs state law claims violate the Foreign Commerce 
Clause. 
COUNT V 
Foreign Affairs Preemption 
 
73.  The United States incorporates by reference all allegations stated 
above. 
74.  The Constitution provides that โ[t]his Constitution, and the Laws of 
the United States which shall be made in Pursuance thereof; and all Treaties made, 
or which shall be made, under the Authority of the United States, shall be the 
supreme Law of the Land; . . . any Thing in the Constitution or Laws of any State 
to the Contrary notwithstanding.โ U.S. Const. art. VI, cl. 2. 
75.  Even aside from his military powers as the โCommander in Chief of 
the Army and Navy,โ U.S. Const. art. II, ยง 2, cl. 1, the Constitutions vests broad 
responsibility for the conduct of foreign affairs in the President of the United 
States. 
76.  The President has โPower, by and with the Advice and Consent of the 
Senate, to make Treaties, provided two thirds of the Senators present concur.โ Id., 
art. II, ยง 2, cl. 2. 
77.  The President โnominate[s], and by and with the Advice and Consent 
of the Senate, . . . appoint[s] Ambassadors, other public Ministers and Consuls.โ 
Id. 
27 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00179     Document 1     Filed 04/30/25     Page 28 of 31  PageID.28
 
78.  The President โreceive[s] Ambassadors and other public Ministers.โ 
Id., , art. II, ยง 3 
79.  The Constitution authorizes the President to โtake Care that the Laws 
be faithfully executed.โ Id. 
80.  In short, โthe supremacy of the national power in the general field of 
foreign affairs . . . is made clear by the Constitution.โ Hines, 312 U.S. at 62. 
81.  The Supreme Court has interpreted the provisions of the Constitution 
that vest authority over foreign affairs in the President to prohibit actions by the 
States that lie outside their traditional and localized areas of responsibility and

more than an incidental effect in conflict with express foreign policy. See

82.  Hawaiiโs state law claims fall outside the area of any traditional state 
interest. They instead regulate โa uniquely international problemโ that is โnot well-
suited to the application of state law.โ City of New York, 993 F.3d at 85-86. 
83.  By adopting the Framework Convention, the federal government 
undertook to formulate foreign policy with respect to the โstabilization of 
greenhouse gas concentrations in the atmosphere at a level that would prevent 
dangerous anthropogenic interference with the climate system.โ  Framework 
Convention, Art. 2. 
28 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00179     Document 1     Filed 04/30/25     Page 29 of 31  PageID.29
 
84.  By attempting to impose liability based on greenhouse gas emissions 
purportedly attributable to worldwide fossil fuel extraction and refining, Hawaiiโs 
anticipated lawsuit could undermine the ability of the United States to speak with 
one voice on a matter of pressing interest around the globe. Hawaiiโs state law 
claims also could complicate the United Statesโ relations with foreign countries 
concerning regulation of greenhouse gas emissions, trade policy, and exports and 
imports of fossil fuels. And Hawaiiโs state law claims penalize extraction and 
refining activities in foreign countries despite the Presidentโs explicit judgment that 
energy imports should be exempt from the tariffs imposed under Executive Order 
14257. 
85.  Hawaiiโs anticipated lawsuit interferes with the United Statesโ foreign 
policy on greenhouse gas regulation, including but not limited to the United Statesโ 
participation in the Framework Convention and announcement of its intention to 
withdraw from the Paris Agreement, and is therefore preempted. 
86.  This claim does not challenge Hawaiiโs authority to enact local 
regulations that incidentally affect international corporations, such as 
environmental standards for in-state operations. Instead, the United States seeks to 
prevent Hawaii from pursuing its state law claims because its imposition of 
liability for worldwide greenhouse gas emissions directly intrudes on the federal 
governmentโs exclusive authority over foreign affairs, including the United 
29 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00179     Document 1     Filed 04/30/25     Page 30 of 31  PageID.30
 
Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change and trade policy. This 
extraordinary extraterritorial reach and conflict with federal foreign policy 
distinguish Hawaiiโs state law claims from ordinary state regulations that do not 
undermine the United Statesโ ability to speak with one voice in international 
relations. 
87.  Simply put, Hawaiiโs attempt โto recover damages for the harms 
caused by global greenhouse gas emissions mayโ not โproceed under [Hawaii] 
law.โ City of New York, 993 F.3d at 91. 
88.  Thus, Hawaiiโs state law claims are preempted by the foreign affairs 
doctrine.
